title: Exercise for Longevity
content: Describes what it means to exercise with the goal of longevity in mind, including personal goals, exercise framework, and optimizing for what is referred to as the 'Centenarian Decathlon.'

title: Cardiovascular Training
content: Explains the various types of cardiovascular training and how to partition your time between intensity levels (i.e., zone 2 training vs. zone 5 training) to optimize cardiorespiratory benefit.

title: VO2 Max and Longevity
content: Dives deep into questions around VO2 max, such as why it’s critical for longevity, how to improve it, and the value in starting VO2 max optimization early in life.

title: Zone 2 Exercise
content: Discusses zone 2 exercise: ideal training methods and how to determine your zone 2 level.

title: Rucking as Exercise
content: Talks about rucking as a versatile mode of exercise.

title: Zone 5 Exercise
content: Discusses zone 5 exercise: modalities of training, time per week, and other considerations.

title: Importance of VO2 Max
content: Explains the importance of knowing your VO2 max, and methods for estimating it.

title: Improving VO2 Max
content: Describes training methods for improving VO2 max, and realistic targets for improvement.

title: VO2 Max and Age
content: Discusses the relationship of VO2 max with age and the required fitness levels for daily life activities and exercise.

title: Maintaining Elite VO2 Max
content: Talks about the training necessary to maintain an elite VO2 max throughout life.

title: Starting Fitness Early
content: Discusses the value in starting early: the compounding nature of fitness.

title: Exercise Topics Discussion
content: There have been a lot of follow up questions after the recent exercise content. Today will be some rapid fire questions going a little deeper on exercise topics. If all goes to plan we’ll cover all four pillars of questions that have come in. It should be a good well rounded AMA on all things exercise.

title: Peter’s Exercise Goals and the Centenarian Decathlon
content: The Centenarian Decathlon is simply a mental model for how to think about training. In long experience with training, something became very clear: Specificity matters. But people confuse specificity with narrow, that’s not the case. You can be broadly trained and broadly conditioned, but with specificity and focus—that’s really what the Centenarian Decathlon is all about. You can be narrowly focused with great specificity, that’s what certain types of athletes are doing.

title: Importance of Specificity in Training
content: For instance, if you’re the best golfer in the world, there are some really, really specific things that you need to be doing. Your training is basically focused on enhancing those very, very specific movements and probably some training to counterbalance the asymmetry there. So it’s very difficult to be successful in a physical endeavor if you are not pursuing some sort of objective. The “I’m just going to work out” strategy doesn’t really produce great results over the long haul.

title: Goal of Physical Robustness in Later Life
content: And we’re going after a really hard problem—which is to be in the last decade of your life, what we call the marginal decade, and be incredibly robust physically. What does that look like to be physically robust in the marginal decade? Imagine a 90 year old who’s functioning like a 70 year old, but that is going to require a lot of preparation.

title: Importance of Specific Training for Aging
content: When you think about the inevitability of decline of muscle mass, strength, cardiorespiratory fitness, you have to be training for that with the same degree of focus and specificity that a person is training for to be an exceptional athlete in their 30s or 40s. The Centenarian Decathlon basically forces us to be specific in what our metrics are in that last decade of life, and it allows us to “backcast” from there. Forecasting from wherever you are today will almost without exception fail to get you where you need to go, because you’ll end up missing the mark by slipping underneath it. Instead you want to start with where you need to be at the very end and work your way backwards.

title: Exercise Framework and Energy Expenditure
content: Today’s training is really focused on something different which are these 4 o 5 buckets: Zone 2, Zone 5, Strength, Stability, Rucking. You can identify energy expenditure by how many METs are required for each activity. How much time you spend in each gives you MET hours per week. And then you can get a sense of where your energy is going. That’s probably the purest way to understand energy expenditure across those domains.

title: Partitioning Time Between Low and High Intensity Exercise
content: What do we know about whether moderate intensity exercise is as good as vigorous intensity exercise? The reality is both are important. And Peter notes that he is now talking about this through the lens of assuming a person’s objectives are somewhat in line with his. This is a big assumption, which is do you want to be 84 years old and kind of able to do anything?

title: Physical Fitness for Daily Activities
content: Peter and his wife just visited Italy (Rome and Tuscany) for a wedding. They had 4 suitcases that they had to lug all around and load them overhead into planes and trains. It was very hot, walking 7 miles per day, and overall it was a very physical trip. As a 50 year old, that trip didn’t phase Peter – but Peter wants to have this same vacation at 75 years old. If you actually look at the energy requirement, the VO2 requirement to do all the stuff I talked about, we’re abutting into the 30 mls per minute per kilogram range. And so there’s a certain amount of strength, stability, and fitness you would need to be able to have that same vacation when you’re later in life.

title: Aerobic Training Intensity
content: A combination of high and low intensity aerobic training, plus a lot of strength training is needed for optimal results. The world’s best athletes spend on average probably 70 to 80% of their training volume in low intensity training. Athletes at that level are spending about 80% of their time, if not slightly more in what we call zone 2 — meaning lactate below two millimole. Zone 2 isn’t that physically challenging, however, their zone 2 is really at a higher level.

title: Training Advice
content: 80 to 90% of training volume from a cardio standpoint should be at zone 2, with the remainder being at zone 5. You can do as much time in zone 1 as you’d like, but we’re not counting that towards your training volume, because you don’t need the active recovery the way the athletes do. The base of the pyramid is your zone 2 capacity, the wider the base of your pyramid, the higher your zone 2 capacity. Your VO2 max, which is your maximum aerobic output, is the peak of the pyramid. If you want to have that high peak, if you want that massive engine, you have to have a huge base. 80/20 is kind of the rule of thumb, which is 80% of your time building the base, 20% shaping the peak.

title: Zone 2 Exercise
content: Bike is a preference for zone 2 exercise, however, treadmill is best for most people starting out. Rowing is a great exercise, but truthfully it’s quite technical. So if you don’t have the technique, you’re going to hurt yourself on a rowing machine for 45 minutes. The biggest impediment to zone 2 is that it’s much easier to do indoors than outdoors and therefore it’s nowhere near as enjoyable. Walking outdoors, generally, isn’t going to cut it because for most people you need some elevation change, meaning an increase, you need to be walking uphill to make it work.

title: Treadmill Exercise for Beginners
content: Beginners can estimate the right pace on a treadmill. Generally have people get to the velocity that is going to be their maximum efficiency, and you’ll know you’re past that, when you feel like you want to start running. We don’t want you running just because of the impact—it’s 8:1 versus 3:1 application of body weight force to knee. Once you get to that maximum point, you increase the grade or elevation of the treadmill.

title: Identifying Exercise Zone 2 without a Lactate Meter
content: There’s the RPE test, and then there’s the heart rate guidance. Use heart rate as the boundary conditions, but ultimately until you get lactate tested, you’re probably going to have to rely on rate of perceived exertion. Heart rate guidance we provide people is triangulating between a couple of numbers.

title: Determining Maximum Heart Rate
content: If a person doesn’t know anything, they don’t know what their maximum heart rate is, they’ve never done anything before, then guidance is 180 minus your age. If you’re really deconditioned, you might be subtracting 10 from that. If you’re superbly conditioned, you might be adding 10 to that.

title: Using Rate of Perceived Exertion
content: Ultimately you default into this RPE state, which is once you lose the ability to talk out loud, not whisper, literally have a discussion with somebody on the phone, you’re out a zone 2. If you’re speaking to somebody on the phone or standing next to you with great ease, you’re below zone 2.

title: Exercise for Deconditioned Patients
content: A person who is wildly deconditioned will have a resting lactate that’s almost two. Lactate is actually a useless proxy for someone who’s very deconditioned, because the minute they start moving their lactate will go from 1.5 to 2.5, but yet they’re barely feeling it. So in those patients we actually don’t want to use lactate. Lactate doesn’t really kick in until a person’s quite fit.

title: Changes in Zone 2 Threshold with Conditioning
content: When you first start doing zone 2 consistently, you will see improvements in your efficiency and therefore your zone 2 threshold may be at a higher output of work. However, at some point you will plateau and the only way to meaningfully increase your efficiency is to add more and more volume of zone 2 work.

title: Rucking as a Versatile Mode of Exercise
content: In terms of what zone you are in while rucking, it’s above and below and in. For example, you’re in zone 1 when on flat areas, you’re above zone 2 when walking on a hill, and when going downhill you’re probably zone 1. At the end of the ruck, your average HR might have been a 130 (therefore zone 1), but that exercise was anything but zone 1 — it’s more like interval training.

title: Importance of Staying in Zone 2 without Interruption
content: It is important to stay in zone 2 without interruption during exercise.

title: Zone 2 and Zone 5 Exercise
content: If you go out for a four hour bike ride and your bike computer comes back and tells you spent one hour of that four in zone 2, that’s not the same as spending one hour straight in zone 2. There’s something about that form of exercise that requires staying in that zone and just letting the body crank through that metabolic pathway without interruption. Rucking on the treadmill is a fantastic way to get zone 2 and do so at a lower speed. Doing your zone 5 via the same modality you do your zone 2 will lead to better crosspollination. If your only form of fitness is on a bike or a rowing machine, you’re missing a little bit of the necessary impact. Therefore, I also think doing some of your zone 5 in that capacity as well, which again could be done on a treadmill with a ruck. Could be done with a ruck sack outdoors, if you can find a long enough hill or could be done on a stair machine.

title: VO2 Max Importance and Estimation
content: The importance of knowing your VO2 max, and methods for estimating it. Gold standard is indirect calorimetry test. You’re in a lab and they’re putting a mask over your face, and they’re measuring with as much precision as is possible. This is still an inexact science of course, but they’re measuring the rate of oxygen consumption and CO2 production. Those two metrics are what allow you to calculate all the variables of interest. O2 consumption of course is all you need to calculate VO2 max. But CO2 production gives you not just how much CO2 you’re making, but it allows you to calculate the respiratory quotient, which then allows you to understand fuel partitioning and total energy expenditure. But just as with zone 2, there are other ways to estimate your VO2 max. If you have a really advanced sports watch, they’ll often have a feature on there that will sort of estimate your VO2 max based on how fast it thinks you’re moving, what your heart rate is, and then how much your heart rate recovers when you stop. Running based tests are also common such as where you run a given distance and then take the time that you ran that distance in, multiply, divide it by something and that’ll give you a VO2 max. How fast you can run a mile, assuming you’re running it all out, can be used to predict your VO2 max. And those running based tests are reasonably accurate.

title: Estimating VO2 Max
content: If you know your maximum MET, you can estimate your VO2 max by multiplying that number by 3.5. Another method to estimate your VO2 max is the Cooper method. This involves running as far as you can in 12 minutes, measuring the distance covered, and then multiplying that by 36 and subtracting 11.3. These are accurate ways to assess your VO2 max. However, it's important to do the test in an activity that you are comfortable doing. If you're not comfortable, the test can grossly underestimate your capacity.

title: Training Methods for Improving VO2 Max
content: There’s a sweet spot in the intervals that you want to be using—you want them to be longer than what most people think of as hit intervals. If you do something like a Tabata, you will increase your VO2 max, however it’s not the “best” for Vo2 max. A Tabata is an interval that looks as follows: It’s about 20 seconds of all out work followed by 10 seconds of rest repeated eight times. This is the quintessential high intensity interval workout. These types of workouts absolutely increase VO2 max. Rucking also increases VO2 max. However, nothing does it better than about the four to six minute interval at about a one to one ratio of rest to recovery. This involves doing four minutes of about as hard as you can go for four minutes, followed by 4 minutes rest in between. The goal is to roughly maintain intensity and a lot of times even try to slightly increase what you can do for each 4 minute interval.

title: Studies on VO2 Max Improvement
content: Studies have shown that longer interval training increases VO2 max. Some of these studies include 'Linear increase in aerobic power induced by a strenuous program of endurance exercise' by RC Hickson et al. 1977, 'VO2max Trainability and High Intensity Interval Training in Humans: A Meta-Analysis' by AP Bacon et al. 2013, and 'High-intensity interval training in patients with lifestyle-induced cardiometabolic disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis' by KS Weston et al. 2014.

title: Understanding VO2 Max
content: VO2 max is a measure of the maximum volume of oxygen that an athlete can use. It is measured in milliliters of oxygen per minute per kilogram of body weight. When trying to boost your VO2 max, you're trying to increase how many liters per minute of oxygen you can consume while minimizing your body weight. The lower you start at, the more you can increase it. One study showed an average VO2 max pre-training of approximately 38 ml/kg/min, and after 10 weeks of strenuous training, it was approximately 55 ml/kg/min. The ceiling on VO2max will be age and training dependent.

title: VO2 Max and Weight Loss
content: Weight loss or fat loss can also increase your VO2 max. This is because the measure is normalized per weight, meaning that if you weigh less, your VO2 max will be higher, assuming your oxygen consumption remains the same.

title: VO2 Max and Age
content: The relationship of VO2 max with age and the required cardiorespiratory fitness levels for daily life activities and exercise varies. There are three curves representing high fitness individuals (top 5% of VO2 max for their age), average fitness individuals (50th percentile of fitness for their age), and low fitness individuals. These curves show that VO2 max generally decreases with age, and the rate of decrease varies depending on the individual's fitness level.

title: Understanding VO2 and its Importance
content: It now shows various activities and explains what VO2 is necessary. Remember VO2 is ventilation rate of oxygen, VO2 max is what is the maximum ventilation rate of oxygen. What this is showing is what is the VO2 for various activities. At the top it’s showing you to run at 10 miles per hour, which is a six minute mile and it’s telling you that’s about a 57 VO2 max. Now, knock that down to running six miles per hour, which is a 10 minute mile—now you’re at about a VO2 of 35. If you want to be able to walk three miles an hour on a flat, that’s about a VO2 of call it 12. If you want to be able to do that on an incline somewhere between 20 and 25, depending on the steepness of it. If you want to climb stairs slowly it’s a VO2 of 32. If you want to be able to go upstairs pretty quickly, that’s closer to 45.

title: Maintaining VO2 Max for Health
content: It’s important for people to understand where activities lie in the broader scope of life. So when he can’t reach a minute ventilation of 32 milliliters of oxygen per minute per kilogram, his life will begin to be physically compromised. The objective is to always make sure his VO2 max remains above 32 mls per minute per kilogram. According to these data, the average person exceeds that limit by about the age of 50. In other words, the average 50 year old is already at that threshold of fitness that I’m saying I don’t ever want to be below.

title: Training for Elite VO2 Max
content: For someone wanting to have an elite VO2 max (i.e., top 2.5 percentile), can you do that if you’re not training more than 75 MET hours per week? HOWEVER, you will need to be training at least 75 MET hours per week, if in addition to training to have that level of cardiorespiratory fitness, you also want to have the strength/stability that matters.

title: Factors Contributing to VO2 Max
content: You can get a sense as to why VO2 max decreases with age when you think about the three things that contribute to VO2 max: 1 – Maximum heart rate, which is a huge contribution to cardiac output. So cardiac output is heart rate times stroke volume. So with each beat of the heart, you’re pumping that stroke volume out around the body, and that’s a big part of what’s delivering oxygen to the muscle. Maximum heart rate declines with age, it’s reported to drop roughly linearly. 2 – Lean body mass of course is a contributor. 3 – Then of course cardiovascular training.

title: Achieving Top VO2 Max
content: Looking at people that are achieving top 5% VO2 max, training 60 MET hours per week total. The amount of time this take really just comes down to how much other training do you want to put in for these other activities (strength/stability). It’s pretty hard to get there below 75 [MET hours per week}, if you’re going to devote 60 [MET hours per week} to your cardiorespiratory fitness.

title: The Value of Starting Fitness Early
content: There’s no area in which compounding plays a greater role than in this arena. It’s even more relevant than in wealth accumulation. If you start saving at 25, it’s a very different proposition than if you start saving at 45 or 55, if your goal is to retire at 65. But the reality of it is with exercise there is no lottery equivalent. There is no inheritance of money or equivalent. Everybody is on the same footing. Everybody is going to have to grind their way through the savings return compounded over time formula to get the benefits when they’re done. Time, intensity, and specificity are going to be necessary components to give you the optionality to be able to be as physically active as possible when you’re in the final decade of your life.
